description: This was so delicious! I had the fattoush salad and it was unexpectedly fresh and delicious. I live a few blocks away and always pass this after hours when it's closed, but worked from home today so I came in for lunch and was very pleasantly surprised. It might be a new neighborhood spot for me!
author: Bianca E.

description:
My husband, mother-in-law, sister-in-law, and I decided to stop in here after visiting our cousin who lives right around the corner. I had Paulie's Pickling bookmarked after seeing it on a local TV show. I liked the concept that it was Paulie's place plus two other mini-restaurants, Mae Krua (Thai) and Peaches Patties (Jamaican) in the one space. 

My husband ended up getting Paulie's Chicken Schwarma (which came with a pickle) and a honey cardamon iced tea. The rest of us ended up at Mae Krua for Thai food. My husband's chicken schwarma was fresh and delicious. He said he loved the combination of spices and the chicken was tender. I had a sip of his iced tea and immediately went and ordered my own. He said he would be back!
author: Kory R.

description: Still great with their updated menu. Yes I was sad that the cheddar jalapeño sandwich of my pregnancy dreams were gone but the chicken shawarma hit the spot.  Maybe the best I've had and can't wait to check out the other items on the menu.  I don't know why I've waited so long to try out the new menu.
author: Sue L.

description:
So here's why I'm only giving a 4... otherwise would've been a 4.5

We came expecting to have home cured lox and corned beef. Menu changed so you know - be warned!

Place was a shared one with two other food establishments. Not a ton of places to sit but we were fine since we came early.

I got a sabich sandwich and my husband got the borekah platter. Both were solid at $10ish each. Wouldn't come back here from east bay just for this place but it was good

A jar of home made pickles cost $8. Looking forward to it
author: Ellyn B.

description: It was delicious. We had the beef kofta with eggplant. It was out of this world. When I first ordered it I thought the price point for it was a little high for what we were getting, but after I took the first bit I thought I was getting it for a bargain. Quick delicious food with great service. It a little hard to find because it's in the Cartland Market place with a few other restaurants. Definitely will come back again.
author: Greg K.

description: I had just returned from a visit to the Middle East where I didn't quite get enough hummus and sabich. I searched through yelp and found Paulie's Pickling and placed my order.  The sabich was absolutely amazing and the hummus was the smoothest I've ever had. I will be back for more
author: Max G.

description: Great service, I totally looked lost. First time trying shakshuka and it was wonderful. Would come again
author: Salene Y.

description: I used to come in regularly for the brisket.  Though, I was disappointed it's no longer offered, the Beef Kofta sandwich was Amazing.  It's one of the best tasting things I've ever eaten.
author: seth c.

description: Spicy lentil soup was decent, though nothing particularly memorable about it. Cool concept overall.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Nestled in a first floor open area, this small sandwich stand really packs a punch in terms of flavor.

I ordered the brisket reuben, and although it was on the expensive side (about $13), it was well worth it. They packed a lot of tender brisket inbetween toasted rye bread, accompanied by vinegar-y pickled greens mixed with a chipotle-esque thousand island-y sauce. Definitely the best reuben I have ever had, and I would be down to come again for sure.
author: Brandon Y.

description: I love this place and wish it were closer. They're super friendly and the sandwiches are awesome.
author: Alli J.

description:
Two words...

Turkey salami.

Yep, salami made from turkey meat.

On an onion roll.

There's been so much dutch crunch in my life lately, I thought I'd change it up.

The service was great.  Friendly & efficient.  We had our sandwich & drinks in about 2 minutes.  

I did a vanilla egg cream.  It was tasty.  A bit too sweet, but tasty.

He had a strawberry shrub.  Delicious!  The winner.

The sandwich was very good.  The pickled cucumbers are a great addition.  Turkey salami, if you like salami, will not disappoint.  And the special pickle you get w a sandwich?  It's pickled w jalapeño...delish.

A great change up from the usual deli fare.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: I was a big fan of the old Paulie's menu and wasn't sure what to expect when Liz decided to move away from classic Jewish deli fare to a Middle Eastern menu. However, once I tried her fattoush salad and sabich sandwich, I was an instant convert. Whatever Liz makes is fresh and delicious -- comfort food of the best kind.
author: Julie F.

description: Beef kofta was to die for. Eggplant, pickles, fragrantly spiced beef, wrapped in very soft, fresh pita. Got it to go, ate it while working at home without much drip-age. It was a well wrapped, perfectly constructed, extremely tasty thing. I do miss their old iteration as a jewish deli, but I'm looking forward to trying everything on their middle eastern menu. It seems the quality of the ingredients, and care in preparation are happily the same.
author: Bubba M.

description: Had an amazing chicken shawarma. Moist, flavorful, and the pickles are a delicious touch. Highly recommended! Located in a cute neighborhood.
author: Emily C.

description:
Very unsatisfying.
Lox and bagel- Bagel was great and probably sourced from elsewhere. No where near enough lox.  Tomato and onion are cut way too thick. Smoked salmon or lox should be the feature but we couldn't even taste it. Oye!!

Brisket sandwich- again brisket should be the feature and all I tasted was kraut. Plus not enough dressing and stale rye.  No balance and expensive at $13. 

On top of that they forgot the smoked fish salad I ordered.  Good thing I didn't pay for it. 
Called them and they were so cavalier about it. 
Based on yelp reviews this place sounded great. Yelp can really go to hell in a hand basket.  
Extremely disappointing!
author: goldberg d.

description:
Making Jewish food taste like something I want to eat more than quarterly is a feat but PP's braised brisket sandwich has changed that. The onion roll (get this on an onion roll if you care about yourself) the brisket, the slaw and I are living the dream.

I do recommend you take mustard off the egg salad sandwich tho. It gives it a sour taste and that's not ideal when you're eating eggs.
author: Kendra S.

description:
3.5 STARS 

When your celebrity chef crush tells you to go somewhere... 

YOU.GO. 

Of course, making sure to wipe off the residual drool from the corners of your mouth before doing so. 

It's no secret that my celebrity chef crush is Ryan Scott. When we visited his restaurant Mason, two months ago, he highly recommended that we try Paulie's Pickling since I live nearby.

Paulie's Pickling is located in the shared marketplace: 331 Cortland (no available seating). Their specialty is as their namesake states: pickles. They have an array of different pickled veggies: cucumbers, green beans, sauerkraut, cauliflower, jalapenos, spicy carrots, etc. which are about $6-$10 per a jar.

They also serve up various Jewish deli-style sandwiches ($7.50-$11.50), bagels and smears ($3.50-$8), salads (price varies on size), and housemade drinks like honey cardamom soda, egg creams, cucumber lemonade ($3.50). Please note that prices on their website are not current. Most items were about $1 more when I visited yesterday. CC's accepted. 

Most 8-year olds would cringe at the thought of eating liver. My classmate did...so much so that she would trade her weekly liverwurst sandwich for my pathetic burnt toast folded over with a slice of ham and imitation cheese. 

When perusing the menu, I immediately gravitated to the Brisket & Liver Combo Sandwich w/ grilled slaw, onion, and Russian dressing ($11.50) http://bit.ly/1x9hOLr. Between a choice of rye, onion roll, sourdough, and wheat, I went with sourdough bread. The sliced sourdough was lightly toasted in the oven so it held everything together quite well. Overall, I thought the sandwich was just OK. For the price, I wouldn't order it again. Just like Ed U., I thought the brisket was very dry and bland. I found myself just picking it out of the sandwich. =/ The slaw gave a nice crunch, however, it lacked acid to cut through the richness of the meats. The highlight was the liver (5 stars) which was decadently rich and creamy (no metallic taste). I'm glad they sell this a la carte because it would make a killer spread over some lightly toasted Acme or Josey Baker bread.  Mmmm....

The sandwich also came with a pickle spear which was perfectly pickled, uber crunchy, and very satisfying. For the price of the sandwich, I wish it came with two spears but anyhow, I would definitely come back for a jar.

A NYC classic, it's rare to find egg creams in SF so I ordered a Vanilla Egg Cream ($3.50) to slurp on while I waited for my sandwich to be made. Loved the prominent vanilla flavor but it was too sweet for my liking. Next time, I would ask for less syrup. 

Service was very friendly and sandwiches took about 8 minutes to be made (only 1 person working).

Easy street parking. 

The sandwich, egg cream, and small tip totaled over $18...for a non-sit down lunch. Eeeeeck. Ahhh, the price of being a wannabe groupie...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
"Check, Please! Bay Area" strikes again. I thought I had a solid handle on all the Jewish-style delis in town, so seeing I missed this one in Bernal Heights made me feel like a shmendrik. Well, you could have knocked me over with a paper towel and picked me up with a pair of silver ice tongs when I saw that this has been in a communal space at 331 Cortland for the past 4-1/2 years. I convinced Jamie W. to accompany me for a Saturday afternoon visit, and I was amazed I was able to find parking just a half-block away. Gee, I wish there were more incubators in the city that allow budding small business owners to share space and cut down on their rent to establish themselves. Married owners Paul and Liz Ashby run their combination deli, bagel and pickle shop in here.

It's clearly the favorite of the six businesses in operation in here. Lots of sandwiches to choose from the whiteboard (photo: http://bit.ly/1rnVWde), but I already knew from a Yelp photo check that I was getting the $10.50 Brisket and Liver Combo with their Grilled Slaw, Russian Dressing and Onion. I ordered it on an onion roll (photo: http://bit.ly/YDDUHo), and I was surprised that the luxuriantly creamy chopped liver overpowered the brisket which was a bit dry and under-seasoned for my taste. The grilled slaw was a nice switch fro the expected mayo-mustard mix lending a welcome smokiness to the sandwich. Jamie was happier with his choice, the $11 Brisket Reuben which more predictably had Sauerkraut, Russian Dressing and Swiss Cheese (photo: http://bit.ly/1vlz9gh).

The ingredients blended more comfortably together in his sandwich, and the sauerkraut, in particular, had a nice fresh taste. Of course we had to have Paul's specialty, the housemade pickles, and we enjoyed the snappy flavor of the garlic dill spears we got (photo: http://bit.ly/1ndYlQm). Just from looking at the display of them in the case, I ended up getting a jar of them to go (photo: http://bit.ly/VGlJ1P). The other temptation I caved into was a $3.50 slice of the Lokshen Kugel, which looked good in the case. Liz warmed it up for me, and it was one of the best slices I've had. I had a good one at Wise Sons, but this was much richer with a custard-like consistency and plenty of egg noodles and raisins (photo: http://bit.ly/1pTnswk). You do have to shlep everything you buy, so they obligingly bag everything up for you. Oy, I'm mishpocheh!

FOOD - 4 stars...Paulie has fine, snappy pickles, but it's the creamy chopped liver and kugel that stand out...though not together
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...the 311 Cortland marketplace concept is very cool...a little seating area would be nice
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...responsive, helpful in explaining the choices
TOTAL - 4 stars...not quite verklempt but Paulie and Liz have reason to kvell
author: Ed U.

description: Not a vegetarian, but had a delicious, flavorful, meat-free wrap for lunch...so good! We also had food from the restaurants that share their rate... Delicious Thai and Jamaican!
author: Nick J.

description: I was a huge fan of the deli menu and I am loving the recently updated menu as well. The albacore gyro is so fresh light and filling and so far my favorite. A great local owner that feels good to support and your reward is tasty food perfect for quick lunch or weekend picnics.
author: Jessica M.

description:
I'm familiar with places like the SF Ferry Building where vendor share the entire building and have their own little spots, but I was a little confused/amazed that the four vendors inside this place decided to do the same, in such a little space.

The menu of Paulie's is mostly cold-cut sandwiches that sound amazing. I've no idea why, but the idea of a liver sandwich on marbled rye sounded like the most delicious thing ever, but alas, we had just come from another bakery and were stuffed. What really caught my eye was their egg cream.

As a child, in books I read with characters in New York (and some tv shows), the egg cream was always mentioned, which to me was a delicious, mythical, confusing sounding drink that I was dying to try, but could never seem to find anywhere I went. Seeing it on Paulie's menu made my order a no-brainer.

A plain way of describing it is as a fizzy yoo-hoo drink, it's 3 layers of chocolate syrup, seltzer and milk, and cream on top, I believe. Based on the drink itself, I'm glad I got to try it, but it isn't necessarily a repeat order from me. I would come by to try the other dishes here, though!
author: Claire S.

description: I just needed to eat a quick bite and so I popped in and got a chicken shawarma. It was so good and the pickles are out of this world. A perfect lunch.
author: J H.

description: Just left my review on 331 Cortland Marketplace but here it is: I just found another SF food gem. 331 Cortland Marketplace. A co op of 3 food vendors whose food all looks amazing, but I opted to try Paulie's Pickling. What a delicious Albacore Tuna Gyro! With homemade pickles, tuna, cucumber tomato salad, tsatiki, all wrapped in a soft pita. Yum!! Washed down with mint lemonade. Incredibly fresh and flavorful.  Definitely coming back to try Peaches Patties Jamaican  and Mae Krua Thai food. All nestled into an immaculate Bernal Heights charming window front. You can opt to sit outside on the benches. Gosh, it doesn't get better than this for a casual sunny Saturday afternoon lunch!
author: Bridget K.

description: Did this place change hands? Their menu is so different now. I was very disappointed to find they no longer have their chopped liver. I used to love this place, but was not thrilled with what I found there today.
author: Dalila S.

description: Still the very best, but make sure the labels do not fall off the jars if you get a bunch, because you may be surprised!
author: George T.

description:
Paulies sandwiches are the BEST!  My favorite is the smoked whitefish (add jalapeños.) I've craved this sandwich and given into my cravings for several days in a row!  the tuna melt is very good as well. All things pickled are to die for. You get a free pickle slice with your sandwich which is a perfect combo. Their strawberry shrub drink is very yummy too!
The people that work there are super sweet and service is quick! Best place for a sandwich in bernal heights!
author: Sarah Z.

description: They have some really great sandwiches here at a reasonable price point. The pickles, of course, are delicious. Great option for lunch if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Diana G.

description:
Located in the 331 Cortland Co-op. Paulie's pickling serves some solid Cali-Jewish inspired locally made food. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/n_JIuho2kJfDMS9pCQYr8Q?select=_IQV4NhqzZG8HYtwCY6tzA)

Picked up their braised brisket sandwich $8.5 with Russian dressing, slaw, swiss, on rye for lunch. It was OK. I liked the amount of brisket they put in, except it was bland and cold. It may not be Kosher to warm it up but I think it'd taste better. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/n_JIuho2kJfDMS9pCQYr8Q?select=MA5qlIy89uc6zoJBchkU6A)

Their sandwich came with their signature pickles as a side, fresh and more tart than the ones you get from a jar. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/n_JIuho2kJfDMS9pCQYr8Q?select=Ib2twGXWY2TputO0nXgrvQ)

My choice would be Avedano's up the block for a sandwich. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/n_JIuho2kJfDMS9pCQYr8Q?select=aOV9kWR0ed-3NO5e3LRgTA)
author: Earl G.

description: The lox along with the lox sandwich are out of this world. The brisket sandwich is also truly amazing.
author: Nic B.

description:
I feel bad for liver.  It gets a bad rep.  But so good for our body.  I think it's the way it's usually prepared.  The worst experience I've had was when my mom forced me to eat sauteed beef liver with onions when I was young telling me that it's nutritious.  Traumatizing.  Traumatizing that I thought all livers were bad tasting.  Paulie's Pickling changed my mind.  
Now you would wonder, why would I pay around $10 for a liver sandwich when I clearly have had traumatizing experience with it.  That's a waste of money.  Well liver is one of the superfoods darnit !  I had to give it another chance and thank God it paid off.  Plus I got the brisket and liver combo sandwich in hopes that brisket will overpower the liver.  

I actually I regret that you can taste the brisket more than the liver.  Upon tasting this sandwich, I was pleasantly surprised how good the chopped liver was.  I actually wanted more of it than the brisket.  i left a piece of my sandwich and gave it to my husband so he can taste it.  He's not a liver lover at all.  I told him to try it.  Well he didn't really like it, but oh well... more for me!  

Been thinking about going back here to eat more liver.  Liver yummmm.  Oh yea the pickle that came with my sandwich was also good.
author: Claire J.

description: Amazing food.Brisket ruben soooo good.Yum
author: mary k.

description:
First off, I'm thrilled that there are more tables!!! Last time I was there, there was only 2 tables and a bench outside the shop. If you haven't been to this place, there are multiple shops in one location, so limited seating! 

I ordered the Ruben sandwich and it was delicious! The meat was moist and the melted cheese complimented the meat so well. The sauce was on the sweeter side and I wish I had more sauerkraut, but my craving for a good sandwich was satisfied. 

My only complaint is that it's expensive for a sandwich - $13.95 (sandwich, quarter of a pickle, and some chips)
author: Stellie L.

description:
Craving one thing and found something entirely AWESOME!

Be forewarned, the sandwiches are a bit pricey but for a first time try or a good sandwich to have on a nice beautiful day to pick up your spirit moreso than already then I say its worth it. 

Got their tuna melt with cheddar on an onion roll was what topped the day off for the gf and me (or I, if you're one of those people). Nice and hot and toasty and when you bite in to it and you'd think the fillings come out to the side but it ALMOST oozed out but didn't which meant we got every single bite of our tuna melts while it was nice and hot. 

Did I mention the sandwich was hot?!

And it comes with slice of pickle which in my opinion was tasty too. Yum! And top it off with their own homemade Honey Cardamon soda--m'mmmmmm (next time gotta try their watermelon lemonade! MUST!!)

Did I mention the sandwich was hot?!

They also have chopped liver sandwich which is peeking my and gf's interest. And they make their own pickles and saurkeraut! Yea, I spelled it wrong and my grammars bad! SUE ME!! I'm about their sandwich now!

Did I mention the sandwich was hot?!
author: Holden L.

description:
Definitely an ideal spot for picking up sandwiches to go before Delores Park.  I split the Lox sandwich and the artichoke hummus veggie, both of which were piled high with fresh veggies and smothered in savory cream cheese and fresh ground chickpeas, respectively.

I would've liked some thicker bread, but the emphasis was more on the filling rather than what held it together.  Normally, this would upset me, but I was so satisfied by the rich ingredients that I wasn't overly bummed by basic, store-bought bread.
author: Rachel H.

description:
My friend recommended this place as an alternative to our usual sandwich spot so we decided to give it a whirl. It was so disappointing.

I got the brisket reuben. It was pretty mediocre, and pricey. I wouldn't mind the price if it had been delicious, but it wasn't. The brisket had more of a barbecue brisket taste than a good Jewish deli taste, and the rest of the ingredients just didn't work well together. 

Service was friendly, but it took FOREVER to get our food. I'm a patient dude, but it wasn't particularly busy. 

The one thing I did enjoy was their pickles. My friend wasn't wowed by them either, but I thought they were solid. Though small. 

Anyway, maybe it was an off day and maybe their other sandwiches are better, but there are much, much better reubens in the city.
author: joe p.

description: Stopped by Paulie's Pickling on a whim, and am so happy about it! Food was delicious and the staff were super-friendly.
author: Rumana H.

description:
Had the chopped liver sandwich (3/5) good but nothing mind blowing. Although the pickle was absolutely delicious (5/5). I would eat a bite of pickle and then sandwich and ran out of pickle before I finished the sandwich. At that point the liver, lettuce, and special sauce tasted the same.

I would recommend buying an extra pickle or jar! : )
author: Leslie K.

description:
It's excellent.

Got the brisket and liver with sourdough bread.

Super friendly too :)
author: Ellie M.

description: I'm new to Bernal Heights and was looking for a quick and filling bite to eat. I looked up spots on my trusty Yelp app and was led here. The 331 Cortland location is a great collaborative space filled with multiple food vendors. I definitely want to try the other two vendors I saw here on another day but I was on a mission to get to Paulie's pickling. I tried their special, the corned beef brisket sandwich, and was so happy I did! It was warmed to perfection and the corned beef was so tender and flavorful. The other flavors of slaw, Russian dressing and cheese added an amazing punch that made the sandwich one of the best I've tried in my life. They give you a pickle on the side (fitting) and it was so good it made me want to buy a jar of them to binge eat later while binge watching the new season of OITNB. Get yourselves here!
author: Sarah F.

description: PAULIE'S JUST GOT EVEN BETTER! While I'll miss their one of a kind Jewish deli sandwiches, their concept has changed to Middle Eastern street food including soup, salads, sandwiches, and shakshuka with eggs. I ordered several of their dishes today and was very impressed. The flavor profiles are very authentic (I can vouch for them because my family is Middle Eastern.) The ingredients were fresh and the dishes were all satisfying with bold flavors. Thank god they still have their pickles and honey cardamom drink as well (no longer with seltzer but as a refreshing ice tea with not too much sugar.) Will definitely be going back...
author: Micah S.

description: Went here based upon yelp reviews. Great food, nice people. The clientele needs to pull the sticks out of their collective ass, but that's the neighborhood. It's a bit expensive, but that's probably also the neighborhood as well. I'll go back again. They gave me a free pickle which was excellent.
author: Robert B.

description: I made it here a few weeks ago and it was great. At first I saw it on TV and thought I try it out. The TV did not lie to me about the quality of the food, it was beyond my expectations. This is not your average sandwich shop because the owners of this place believe you should get the most out of the money you pay for your food, if you want to splurge go to Panera. Those guys just make knock offs of this place. Even worse, Panera does the opposite of Paulies.  There are big portions for customers to eat. Getting here is not that bad as well because a BART station is right down the road. There is also ample Muni service available because the eatery is located in the Excelsior neighborhood. You can also order some pickles by the bottle. Not everything you see on TV is good but this place rocks
author: Michael W.

description:
This place is just perfect!  You can taste every ingredient in their sandwiches...always so fresh!  Did I mention the pickles?  The cucumber salad?  Also a must!  

Stop in!!
author: Valerie R.

description:
I used to love going to Paulie's fairly often until I realized almost every time I went back the prices got higher and higher. I would usually treat myself to a brisket and liver or a reuben but now I can no longer justify spending almost $15 on a sandwich alone (for the tastiest offerings). I had already began phasing it out of my diet but now I probably won't go back despite living blocks away. Just this year I think the brisket and liver has gone up almost $4. I have a neighbor friend who refuses to join me when I go to this place for just these reasons. The "under $10" given to this business only applies to a couple things on the menu.

They also never ask if I want my bread toasted which should be done by default but only is if you get cheese which costs extra. Pickles are great, they give you one quarter spear and they will give you two quarters if you ask (they used to do this by default). I used to also get a Russian pear soda from the place adjacent to Paulie's in this co-op but now it seems 2 of the food stands at this address have had to leave but I guess it doesn't affect me anyway since the money I'd be giving them ends up going to Paulie's now anyway in the form of raised prices. It's the little things that killed this place for me, but I'm sure this place will still thrive without me because of all the rich yuppie asshats that have flocked to this neighborhood. Make sure to pay them no mind when they give you dirty looks for pulling up a chair across from them at one of the 2 small tables in here while you wait for your order.
author: Sky M.

description:
I HAD THE BEST TUNA MELT SANDWICH OF MY LIFE HERE YESTERDAY!!!!!!!! (I ordered it without onions though, I don't know if that matters for this review. haha What can I say, I don't like onions.) 

Since this place is located in a shared marketplace, my friend and I had a hard time deciding where to go. We had picked out Paulie's Pickling beforehand but it was still difficult deciding.  

The customer service did it for us. It sealed the deal because the man and woman behind the counter gave us tips. (we were struggling because everything looked good) 

The man (sorry forgot to ask for your name) told me the tuna melt was one of the most popular. I felt like he read my mind because I was eyeing it on the menu. HAHA! 

My friend and I went to eat our sandwiches at Holly Park. We found a picnic table and sat down. Thank you for the suggestion man who works at Paulie's Pickling! We had a delicious meal with a beautiful view! 

Paulie's Pickling, I will definitely be coming back due to your wonderful customer service and delicious sandwiches! It's getting close to lunch time and I'm thinking of going back today for some more.... It WAS THAT good.
author: Dania H.

description:
This place is located in Bernal Heights and while it's not usually a neighborhood I come to, I was happy I stopped in for a sandwich. After a busy morning and afternoon I needed to refuel and this really hit the spot. I got the egg salad sandwich and it was very delicious. The eggs were perfectly cut and not mushy at all. It wasn't overly loaded with mayo like at some places. The bread was fresh and delicious and the other ingredients were as well. 

This spot shares it's location with other vendors. There's a waffle place, salad vendor, Russian hot pockets and some kind of Asian  stand. It's really clean inside and they were busy. They have lots of other sandwiches as well, like brisket (house made), tuna melt, Reuben, pickled jalapeño melt, etc. I believe they make all the meats in house. 

They also have pickled vegetables like cauliflower. I tried a pickle and it was very good. I'm definitely going to stop in for a jar of pickles in the future. I also tried a homemade soda and it was the most delicious soda I have ever tasted. Very crisp and light. Everything they have is house made and fresh and delicious. I'll definitely be back.
author: Sam W.

description: This is more of a 3.5. I've never really been to Bernal Heights and decided to venture out of my cave and try something different. I ordered the tuna melt and brisket rueben sandwich at Paulie's Pickling. Both sandwiches were very good, but for $10 i've had better sandwiches (e.g. Deli Board is one of my favorites). However, the pickles here are amazing and I wouldn't mind coming back to get a jar of them.
author: Cindy A.

description: I go here for the sandwiches. The not from a can tuna is GREAT. My family is also a big fan of the brisket.
author: teddy w.

description: LOVE the smoked whitefish spread and their lox. Before Paulie's, I've found that some of the local Mollie Stones locations (e.g., the one up on Portola Dr near Diamond Heights) have the best whitefish I've found in SF. Paulie's whitefish spread is just a touch smokier than Mollie Stone's, same consistency, which puts Paulie's above imo.
author: j k.

description: I don't like pickles and haven't had Pauline's....but I like brisket, and I like Pauline's brisket. I strangely haven't had a sandwich there but have just braised brisket to go. The brisket is incredibly tender and flavorful. It was ~$8 for about 1/2 lb so the price is pretty good but probably not the way to go if you're looking to feed a lot of people.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Sandwiches like I used to get back home at the local Jewish Deli. So good and not so huge that they are falling all over you while you eat them.  
::  Brisket on Rye is to die for.
::  Tuna Salad on Onion Roll...WOAH
::  Great bagels with schemer  - caper schemer, lox, onion and tomato is my fav.
::  Tapioca Pudding with pineapple - so refreshing

Let's not forget what they do best...PICKLES!  Crunchy cold dills - spicy or not, I haven't met one at Paulie's that I haven't loved.
author: Katie S.

description:
Bernal heights, cortland ave. in particular, is a wonderful street to wander on when you've got a few hours and a need for sunshine. Holly park is peaceful and the views unique, also a scenic dining spot.

So, after entering the food court that houses paulie's pickling, i transported my 1 lb. of brisket and chicken liver on marbled rye to the park where i dined under the accusatory eyes of my dog. The dog that never remembers i just shared another bite. Good thing that sandwich is stuffed cuz it's meant to be shared. Pickled cabbage, russian dressing, the aforementioned  meat and liver, and a crispy dill pickle. Right around $10, and well worth it.

This being my only visit to paulie's, i can't say too much about their other comestibles, but that deli dreamwich made me want to go back. 

The food court also offers piroshkis, juices, spices and waffles. Many choices, many sunny days to come, i will be back!
author: Kelly K.

description: Yum! A store within a store! They have jars of pickles and individual whole pickles for $1.00!!! So yums. Zesty original definitely has a kick but their garlic dill is sweet and Delish :)
author: Diana L.

description: Turkey salami was great. Try it on an onion roll with their special veggie sauce. Hella good. Pickles are great too. Will be back!
author: Merle D.

description:
Paulie's Pickling was on a show we saw. Hubby bookmarked it and we made plans to stop by after taking the kids to watch a movie at the Metreon. 

Paulie's is located in Bernal Heights. It's a quiet area with lots of local businesses. We bought 2 jars of zesty original pickles. Evan wanted a white fish sandwich that he shared with his twin and we got a bite of. The sandwich was pricey but yummy. The pickles are pricey $8/jar. I call Paulie's gourmet pickles for the price you pay but you get $0.50 off when you bring back the jars. 

Pickles are pricey but since our first visit we've been back to try their pickled jalapenos and green beans. All very tasty and worth the price when we are craving pickles. What can I say? My family LOVE pickles!
author: Anna K.

description: I have wanted to come here for a long time and I was really disappointed. I had the brisket sandwich. The meat was dry while the rest of the sandwich was soggy due to the junk that they added. The sandwich cost $12. What a scam.
author: Ravi K.

description:
The best chopped chicken liver - it's not creamy smooth like pudding, there's some texture and for me it's perfection. The chopped liver pate is full of complex flavors from her pickles, the hard cooked eggs and what ever else she puts in there.  

A pint or a half pint makes the ideal lazy-girl's dinner!  Or something to bring to a party.

She also makes delicious and super fresh horseradish.  

The germ-phobe in me loves that she washes her hands frequently.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description: Today was my first Paulie experience and I WILL be back. Great food. Great people. My brisket and liver on rye was 100% off the charts good. Tonight I will dig into the Kugel and share some Rugalach and Black and White cookies with friends. Yum
author: Hebrew H.

description: Love love love this place. The brisket Reuben is my favorite - juicy brisket, sharp and tasty sauerkraut, great bread. Heaven.  Pickles are fantastic. Woo!
author: Mary Z.

description:
I miss working in the neighborhood!  This place is so good.
I love their smoked whitefish, their homemade sodas and egg creams, and owners Liz and Paul, who are lovely, funny people and amazing cooks!
Do yourself a favor and take home a few jars of pickles for yourself and for gifts.  I love the pickled green beens.
author: Aileen J.

description:
I Love Paulie's Pickling. There is an abundant variety of pickled vegetables like cucumbers, green beans, japaneos, cauliflower, and sauerkraut in addition to all sorts of sandwiches from liver to brisket to tuna. The boyfriend got the pickled Jalepeno cheddar melt to take home since we visited the place after eating lunch. When we ate it a couple of hours later, the sandwich remained fresh despite the cheese solidifying..It was delicious! The flavors just meshed so well. I usually don't eat Jalapeno, but in this case, I was hooked! It was slightly spicy and slightly refreshing. The sandwich also came with a spear of garlic dill pickle. It was crisp and flavorful; perfect for a hot sunny day. The beverage that ended our day right was the egg cream. I always thought the drink was really made from eggs... but there isn't any... Confused? I am! How can something taste so milky, so vanilla-ey have such an egg foam consistency? I don't understand it?! Like I said, Paulie's Pickling has become one of our favorite spots. If it's not the vanilla egg cream, then it's the sandwiches. 

To couples looking for a good sandwich shop for a nice picnic at the park-- Come here! You won't be disappointed. You get the pickles, the drinks, the sandwiches, and little mini sweets for the go.. What more do you need.
author: Samantha W.

description: Great sandwiches!  Came here for lunch and was impressed.  Good food made with care.  Full sandwiches come with a pickle so you can try one that way with out buying the jar.  Definitely a place to grab lunch to go when you want a decent deli style sandwich.
author: Dayna S.

description: Love this place SO much. Actually, I am heading there now. Came to Yelp to see if I should try something new there. Hmm I think I'll get the jalapeño cheddar. Maybe the tuna salad. It's really hard to choose. Everything here is delicious. Can't wait to have all of it in my mouth! Mmm pickles!!
author: Erin F.

description: Egg salad sando on an onion roll was really good. Would've liked a toasted roll. Pickle was yummy. Tried my friend's veggie sando (artichoke, hummus, etc) and it was GREAT. I could taste every ingredient.
author: Whitney M.

description:
I saw this one on "Check Please Bay Area." As a sandwich fan, I was extremely excited to head over and try it out. I had the tuna salad and the wife had the braised brisket. It was...ok. Brisket was a bit salty, and the tuna, while fresh (not canned), didn't have much flavor. Same with the grilled slaw- no flavor. 

Both sandwiches looked amazing, so I left feeling almost confused- was it an off day? Was it just us? Was I in a bad mood? It wasn't bad, just blah. Anyway, I will probably try it out again if I'm in the area, but likely won't make a special trip. 3 stars for now.
author: Mike K.

description:
This brisket sandwich on marble rye bread changed my life.

Everything works perfectly together. The bread (excellent), the brisket (mouthwateringly delicious), thousand island dressing (creamy mmm), slaw (crunchy) and then I added provolone to my sandwich. Next time I'll try swiss. The pickle was also good. The sodas intrigue me, but paying almost $4 for a soda is a bit more than I can handle.
author: Aurora K.

description:
I keep calling this "Pauline's Pickling," perhaps because only a Jewish grandMOTHER could make brisket this good.

The brisket is reason enough for Paulie's to be my favorite sandwich shop in San Francisco. But then, they offer marble rye bread.

MARBLE RYE. In San Francisco. This former New Yorker is verklempt. They even cut it in thick slabs, which is wise, or else the brisket would escape.

The half brisket sandwich is more than enough for lunch for me. Especially since I'm eating one a week. The only downside of the half sandwich is that it doesn't come with a pickle.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I can't believe I dragged myself not once, not twice, but 4 times to Bernal Heights for a bunch of pickles.  My favorite are the Zesty Original pickles.  I feel like a pregnant lady camped out on the couch, muching on one delicious crunchy spicy pickle after another.
The sandwiches, while decent, are no match for the fantastic pickles.
One star off however for how pricey they are ($8/jar).  I understand they are made with love from probably the freshest available vegetables, but still, ouch.
author: bao t.

description:
I have to say that I am totally and absolutely shocked to see that Paulie's Pickles only has 4.5 stars.  Really based on the pickle I just ate... they should have like... 8 stars.  

We live in Bernal. We love Bernal. We love it even more when local businesses sell amazing products.  

We've only had the Zesty Original pickles.  They just happen to be the BEST-PICKLES-I-HAVE-EVER-EATEN-IN-MY-WHOLE-LIFE-EVER. For example, I have never gotten out of bed at 2am to eat a pickle (or 3) in my life, but you can bet your favorite pair of shoes, that this beez was standing in a dark kitchen eating pickles out of the jar the other night.
author: Lani N.

description:
Come here for the sandwiches not so much for the pickles.  I was really impressed with the sandwich I had the other day but I bought a jar of green beans and the produce was sub par - very stringy beans and not the best brine. 

Get a sandwich to go and go down the street and eat it at Stray Bar you won't be sad about that!
author: Coral H.

description:
I give them 3.5 stars. This is my second time there so far I've tried the following:
Pickle of course, Paulie's pickle was tasty :) I got the brisket liver sandwich, I was scared the liver would be real livery tasting but it was a great compliment to the REALLY MOIST Juicy brisket! Good stuff. I also tried the egg salad with liver on rye bread, also delicious. But I don't know what it is I can't give them 4 stars because I'm not dreaming and running back, BUT I will go back if I'm craving a HUGE juicy brisket sandwich.
author: Karen T.

description:
I'd been reading about Paulie's for quite some time on Yelp (since it opened, I think) and had been putting off my visit because it is a bit out of the way for me.

The day I finally decided to try it was the happiest day of my life.

Okay, not the HAPPIEST, but I cannot remember the last time I've been to a deli this good. 

Yes, the location is a bit strange (it's all the way in the back of a sort of haphazard indoor "marketplace," if you can call it that) and Bernal Heights may be a trek for the Downtown/Nob Hill types, but you HAVE to come to Paulie's. Like, yesterday.

The whitefish is amazing. Does white fish paste sound disgusting to you? It might. I asked to try some and even considered taking back my request after I saw what it looked like (white-fish-paste-goo). To think I almost made the biggest mistake of my adult life.

In all serious, the whitefish was one of the best things I've tasted. Granted, I have not actually had whitefish anywhere but here, but alas, angels were singing that day.

My friend ordered the brisket and liver sandwich--equally fantastic.

I cannot wait to return for another whitefish sandwich. I dream about it!
author: Sara D.

description: Really cute shop, shared with two other vendors, located in Bernal. Paulie's was run by a few teenagers when we went in, which was great to see young ones working away on a weekend. I remember those good ole days! The sandwiches were a bit too over orchestrated for my tastes. Not a classic deli style sando, but more artisan. Artisan can be fine, don't get me wrong. But the Ruben didn't taste like a Ruben at all. A bit over-re-inveted.
author: Tawnee K.

description:
Bernal heights is such a cute neighborhood! Had this bookmarked for a while and was craving a sami so finally decided to try this place on a Sat. Found parking easily and made our way into the food hall where Paulies shares a space with other food vendors. Got their recommended brisket and liver on rye, zesty pickle, cucumber salad, and regular brisket sami.

Brisket and liver was very tasty. Very messy too. Salad and half sami combo was $6.
Full Brisket sami was $10.
 yes a bit hefty for a sami, but it was a decent size and you can tell quality ingrediants were put into it.

Why only the 3 stars? for me more of a novelty than a regular place I'd go to. The highlight for me was the home made pickle. Yes its $8 a jar but that is probbaly the only thing I'd go back for.

Will try the piroshki place next time- oh and the bacon waffles next door is a MUST!!
author: Petri Y.

description:
Really good spicy jalapeño pickles, and carrots. I love them but they are not cheap. 
It is a cool stand to frequent on occasion
author: isaac t.

description:
I was on my way to Avedano's for meat, when I stumbled upon Paulie's Pickling located in the back of the food vendor co-op storefront.

Paulie was in the open kitchen prepping some pickles (garlic dil and zesty) when we arrived, and he immediately popped out to offer us some fresh samples. Mmmmm! Loved the zesty... they're so much better than any store-bought pickle.

After browsing his refrigerated jars, I decided on a jar of pickled brussels sprouts. Slightly spicy, briney and garlicy! I'd never seen pickled brussels sprouts before, and Paulie explained how painstakingly difficult it was to prep the crunchy half-globes. He said he's probably never attempt it again, so I snapped up a jar... wish I had gotten two!

Go support this wonderful little pickle store! It's worth the trip to Bernal.
author: Lauren H.

description: I love this place. Awesome sandwiches. My two favorites together California and Jewish cuisine, I could not ask for more!!! I recently  moved to Bernal and this is my fav spot on the hill. Everything here is super fresh high quality. There is a lot of love in the pickling.
author: Jim K.

description: I stumbled into Paulie's on a random Sunday stroll, and Lord Almighty, I will definitely come back regularly! I had the Brisket Reuben with a classic dill & garlic pickle and a Ginger Celer-ade soda fountain drink.I chewed as slowly as possible to savor each bite of this beautiful creation! My only regret is that I didn't have a bigger stomach to enjoy a dessert! Did I mention the vibe is super friendly, and the decor is unique and well-done?
author: Pam F.

description:
THESE PICKLES ARE CRAZY.

Some might say that I'm crazy to drive all the way across town to get a pickle. Well, I have news for you. I once flew across the COUNTRY for a pickle. Guss Pickles, the iconic  barrels filled with brine out front on the Lower East Side. Sadly, it exists only now as Ess-A-Pickle in Brooklyn, due to the rising rents in Manhattan. Mother of god. Those were great pickles.  

If you have only had supermarket pickles, you just don't understand. Okay, let me try to explain. It's the difference between filet mignon and a Hungry-Man minute steak, between freshly made yogurt drizzled with honey on a warm day on a Greek island versus Yoplait, tomatoes grown in your back yard versus the round red supermarket orbs.

So, I can't keep having them FedEx me pickles from Brooklyn. I always look locally, and I am always very disappointed.

Until now.

So I go to Cortland and it's a tiny shopfront in a cooperative store, a deli with fresh cookies for Hannukah no less. Liz was behind the counter. I'm not sure why other people say she's not friendly. She's just from Boston!  That IS friendly by Boston standards. By Manhattan standards, she would be a loquacious laggard. In the LES, the extent of the conversations is: 
"Quart of Spicy."
"That's five bucks...next!"

Me, I thought Liz was quite nice. We chatted a bit; she let me sample a bunch of different stuff. And, the pickles. 

Wow.

Perfect crunch, great flavor. The kind you just can't stop eating until they are gone. Me personally, I like a tad less dill and a touch more garlic, but I'm not complaining! I can get REAL pickles on the West Coast finally!!!

And pickled green beans! And lox! And a nice lean Reuben! And an egg cream! Oy gevalt!

Also, the sauerkraut is delicious! I bought a pint. Now when I went to use it after a week, it looked a bit off although it smelled fine. Now I pickle at home. Okay, actually I TRY to pickle at home, and... look, let's not dwell on this okay. Let's just say there were some disasters and I am no longer allowed to pickle at home. BUT, I thought it was okay, but I gave Paul a call just to ask. He says to bring it by the shop. Liz and I both look at it, and agree it's fine. BUT, she takes it and right on the spot fills up a new fresh jar of sauerkraut from the back for me. 

Come on, where do you see that kind of phenomenal customer service these days! Above and beyond the call of duty, guys! But I won't complain for outstanding service.

Makes me want to buy a quart of pickles a week. Looking forward to half-sours and (cross fingers) horseradish pickles in the Spring.

Seriously, just go to Paulie's already!
author: Adrian B.

description:
I've tried the Tuna, the Salmon and the Brisket sandwiches.

Brisket wins, hands down! - but the others are good too.

You can't really go wrong here. Solid sandwiches, and the brisket kicks!
author: Shawn S.

description:
A great deli! By far the BEST homemade pickles myself and the 10 friends (so far, more every week!) have had. I love the spicy dill's. 
The sandwiches are remarkable. I wasn't even hungry and my friend had me take a bite of her sandwich .... I ate half of it on a full stomach... It was that good! Brisket with homemade liverwurst. I never knew I liked liverwurst. 
Pickles " seem" A bit pricey... Until you taste them:) Worth buying a few jars.
You will get hooked on them!
author: karl r.

description:
Delicious!! Delicious! Delicious!!!!!! All I can say about  three sandwiches I tried at this place - Brisket, liver, Smoked White fish. Perfect size for lunch  - 1/2 sandwich+small salad ( looked too small for me first time, but turned out to be just enough!) for $5?!!!! 
Coming back there 3-4 times a week ( she is closed on Tuesday). 
The best place for lunch I found for myself in this area!
Recommended!!!!!
author: ina a.

description:
"This is more than what I thought a pickle could be."  Actual quote of mine to the folks at Paulie's. 

Few people would ever ponder the potential of a pickle, so I'm forgiving myself for writing this. Odd as it may sound, my mom's side has imputed me with a real taste for pickles. Think about it though: not many foods can deliver such a variety of flavors and textures in such a small piece of food

Get a jar of Paulie's Zesty Original...don't be shy! Definitely worth the $8. You can try a taste of the Garlic Dill too, just so you'll be able to relate to their pickles, but the Zesty Original takes the concept of a pickle to another level. You know pickle juice is supposed to boost your endurance, right? I know, ewww. Try to think of it like an artisan sports drink with dill, onions and jalapeno.

For a more traditional taste, try one of their sandwiches. I ate the brisket and chopped liver on rye and absolutely loved it! Rarely do I like beef liver or brisket but this combo, plus Russian dressing, onion and grilled slaw, was awesome. Rye bread always tastes good to me and this sandwich was definitely elevated by it. As a fairly dense bread the rye held everything together really well too. I'm always kinda messy when eating, and I never shy away from messy foods, but this sandwich could have been much worse without rye.
author: Mike H.

description: Only the best chopped liver I've ever had, and this includes my very own mother's!  This is bar none the best deli this side of  New York.  The pickles, OMG, the pickles!  One could write poetry about the pickles.  These people are the best.  Thanking the Universe for Paulie's Pickling!
author: David C.

description:
Being a NYC transplant and from growing up in Skokie, IL... I get the occasional craving for good Jewish deli food. Paulie's fits the bill and does a great job satisfying my pickle fix.

Pickles are prepared with love and care - I've spotted Paulie here more often than not making batches and he's always super friendly and passionate about his job.

The Zesty Original has a great, complex flavor - ever-so-slightly sweet, sour, a dash of spiciness, and perfectly salty.

Might not be Gus' but I'll be darned if you can find me a better place in SF.
author: Scott H.

description: Braised brisket is delicious, but it's a really small sandwich. You will be hungry again shortly after.
author: Sofia M.

description:
On 3 different occasions I've had sandwiches of: lox, brisket and whitefish. All were absolutely excellent!  As for the pickles: I am not a fan of any pickles of any sort, so I am unfit to judge, but both of my children who are very picky eaters say the garlic/dill pickles from here are their all time favorites. A real treat of a place, a bit hard to find, but well worth it.

I read someone's post here complaining that they had 2 sandwiches and were still hungry. If whoever wrote that is reading this: you should consider gastric bypass surgery. I was absolutely stuffed three quarters of the way through my whitefish sandwich, and just halfway through my brisket
author: Joshua Z.

description: Beef brisket sand on marble rye is awesome with a very generous amount of brisket.  No seating, but the park is close by and there are a couple of small sitting areas (no tables though) right outside.
author: Paul K.

description:
What a surprise. Keep meaning to stop by and finally did today. 

Brisket Sammie - amazing!  Tender brisket, perfect slaw & Russian dressing on great rye!

Pickled cauliflower - so crazy great. Ate it all immediately. Perfect brine, perfect crunch. I'm gonna use the excess brine for a pickleback party this weekend. 

Going back next week to try the chopped chx liver and maybe an egg cream. 

SF is getting it's deli on in Bernal.
author: Candy G.

description: I got the egg salad/ tuna sandwich, which was good, but not something I'd go out of my way for.  The pickles are fantastic.  I got the regular zesty because it had a kick from the jalapeno, as well as a strong garlic flavor.  This made me think the garlic and dill might be too garlicky for me.  Next time, I'll also get a jar of the green beans, and maybe some sauerkraut.
author: Seong P.

description:
This place is like a few square feet of the Lower East Side transposed to Bernal Heights--and yes, that is a beautiful thing.  I split a house cured lox sandwich with my wife, which was amazing.  It was bursting with tasty fish and the fresh bread roll was really good (the caper spread was also a nice touch).  I want to come back to try the brisket.  We had the rugelach for dessert, which were good but not great. 

I also bought a jar of the garlic and dill pickles which I am slowly working my way through.  They are excellent and better than anything from a supermarket.  Crisp and flavorful, the brine is just right.  Also got some whitefish spread to go which was great the next day on bagels, and later in the week on a sweet baguette for breakfast.
author: Aaron S.

description: Brought in gluten free bread and they made sandwiches with it for me and my gf.  Delicious food. I had the beef briscut/liver and a tuna melt. Both were excellent. Would love to try the liver alone :)
author: Scott C.

description:
Mmm...this place is gooood!!

The boyfriend and I took the dog for a walk at Bernal Hill, and were hungry!  I remember seeing this place on an SF-based show (can't remember the name), where Paulie (one of the owners), showed the host how to pickle some cucumbers.

This place is no joke.  We had the brisket (really good with some melted swiss) and a some garlic pickles.  Amazing!  I bought a tub of whitefish spread to bring home and eat with toasted bread or crackers.  It stays fresh for a good week, and the flavor of the whitefish was not fishy, but light and had the perfect amount of salt in it.  We also bought a jar of the spicy pickles for home.  $8 a jar is a bit pricy, but I swear, they are the best pickles I've ever bought.  Worth every penny.
author: Jessica D.

description:
Walked into 331 Cortland today without a dining agenda, saw Paulie's big "sandwiches" sign and went straight for it.

Had the Tuna Salad sandwich with the house spread and extra jalapenos, with a couple of pickles thrown in on the side.

Messy good food.  Always feels good to support a local startup.
author: Eric M.

description:
man, this place is so good.
When you wander in on a Saturday morning/afternoon miserably hungover and desperately fiending one of their reubens, they will make you one, and it will be heavenly. Piled high with crunchy, tangy, sauerkraut, toasted just right.  Even if they happen to be out of their mind-blowing corned beef, they'll improvise and make you one with brisket! And it'll hit the spot and you might have to eat it in two sittings cause it's so huge.
author: Kay M.

description: I've seen Paulie's Pickling at the Cortland Marketplace for a while now, but for one reason or another, never ordered anything from them.  Two weeks ago, I ordered the beef brisket sandwich and boy, was I surprised.  Being a transplant from Austin (over 15 years ago), I'm always on the hunt for a great brisket sandwich and lo and behold, I found one within a few blocks from my house.  The first time I ordered a full sandwich on their fresh onion roll and the flavorful and tender brisket combined with the coleslaw and dressing was perfection.  The 2nd time, I ordered a half sandwich (on Rye this time) with a side of pickled cucumber salad.  YUM!  The acidity in the cucumber salad lends nicely to the generous brisket portions of the sandwich.  Really happy to have found a great sandwich place in the neighborhood.
author: Molly H.

description:
I wish wish wish wish wish wish wish that Paulie would come and open up a Jewish Deli in Austin, Texas.  

Paulie's makes home made chopped liver, home made tuna salad from cooking sushi grade tuna, flaking it and making a delicious salad out of it.  They make  tuna melts!  They make sandwiches from hand cut fresh made marble rye.  They make their own delicious salads.  They sell home-canned pickles, horseradish, herring and other delicious delights.  

They charge very reasonable prices for big delicious sandwiches. 

Come see Paulie and let them make you a sandwich!
author: Stephanie S.

description: The white fish. I drove 30 minutes out of my way to try the white fish. It was WONDERFUL!!!! I was in heaven. And I found parking on the street. The chopped liver is really good too, like a deli's. I am used to my wife's which has cayenne pepper and worcester sauce. It's a dip which we drink with red wine. The egg cream looked good. I did buy the kugel which I will eat tonight? Tomorrow.
author: Glen G.

description:
Two sandwiches. About 16 dollars with tax. And still hungry afterwards.

Located right up the street, I live about a 3 minute walk away from Paulie's Pickling. My sister was extremely hung over and I personally needed to escape the house to grab some lunch so I thought to myself, "I'll stop by and try out that new pickling shop. They've got sandwiches. It should be good." Or so I thought.

Our two sandwiches, a Brie baguette and a Brisket + Chopped liver came out at a turtles pace but it's understandable since they were toasting the creations in a mini convection oven. All sandwiches come with a side pasta, tabbouleh, or bean salad which helps but doesn't make up for the failed expectations from the sandwiches.

After only a 3 minute walk home, both sandwiches weren't luke warm. They were nearly cold. Have you ever had a brisket and chopped liver sandwich cold? Ya, I don't believe so. Putting that aside, the flavors weren't exactly all there and the "chopped liver" had more of a pate smear texture. So, when accompanied with the sloppy joe style brisket the sandwich had a chunky pudding like structure. 

I didn't get a chance to try any of their pickles but after having a sandwich I believe it's easy to say that Paulie's Pickling should stick to well... Pickling.


Until next time. This was Spencer C.
author: Spencer C.

description: Three words....BEEF BRISKET REUBEN!!! Its easily one of the best sandwiches in the city! Also, the homeade pickled items are awesome. BUT, the toaster oven they use dries out their otherwise awesome bagels :/
author: Mojo M.

description:
Get the brisket, substitute a side for a pickle.  Paulie is nicer than his wife, who is a bit surly.  But I kind of like that, since it is pretty unexpected on "rainbows and babies" Cordland Avenue. 

Look at knives while they make your sandwich.

Great place to snack with Sample the dog.
author: AP R.

description:
The garlic dill pickle is hands down the best pickle that I have ever had! 

 I'm seriously addicted to everything I tried- I don't know if he's pickling crack and putting it in every jar, but whatever it is, it is amazing!!!
author: Tasha R.

description:
Packed brisket Sammie on rye is very tasty, enough for two meals. White fish 
A big winner for Paulie's. Only three stars because chopped liver wasn't yet ready by noon. Owner explained they had too many customers so couldn't find time to prepare that item. What?? Only two behind the counter for a steady stream of customers. Paulie's is not ready for prime-time and unprepared for success. Not able to offer one of their few menu items for lunch is inexcusable. Whining that there were too many customers is ridiculous. Hoping they get it together soon so they can be ready to serve what they advertise.
author: Joan P.

description:
"So what am I to you....chopped liver??"  is an expression usually associated with sour grapes, bad vibes...being unfavorably compared to someone or something "no bueno".   Well  Sir/Madam, I can assure you...if you ever find yourself being compared to the chopped liver at Paulie's PIckling, consider yourself  officially "all that!"  Paulie's Picking...a booth in the cool co-op that is 331 Cortland, has a small but memorable menu of offerings...on the sandwich front...may I just say..yum and wow!  Definitely look into their brisket...or egg salad...or tuna salad or...chopped liver sandwiches!!  None will disappoint..except maybe when you finish one and think "gee, it's over? More please!"  They'll whip up an egg cream to enjoy while you wait for your sandwich...oh..and they have creamy/dreamy tapioca pudding..original AND a yummy coconut version!!  This gem is a microcosm of the Carnegie Deli in NYC...only here in SF,  in sunny Bernal Heights!  Save yourself the airfare sonny and hot foot it over to Paulie's! 

ALSO..lest I leave out...Paulie IS a pickler! (Hmmm..wonder if he's any relation to Peter Piper who picked a peck of pickled peppers?!)  Listen up...  If  anyone you know tries to hassle you...and asks "$8.00 for a jar of pickles?! Really??? Tell them to "brine their own business!"  These pickles are the real deal and if you need to verify that, no worries, Paulie P and his crew will let you sample whatever you point to in that refrigerated display case! They will answer question after question about pickles and veggies, and tell you about the brine and the spices that they used, ad nauseum!  My personal faves are: Paulie's Garlic Dill and Paulie's  Spicy Original!  And when you are finished, if you bring back the pickle jar, they will give you a $.050 credit on your NEXT jar of heaven, I mean pickles!  A dilly of a deal!

I hand "pickled" Paulies Pickling to review for #250!   Here's to you, Baron of the Brines...Earl of Egg Creams....Prince of Pickles!
author: Karen S.

description:
Digging the 311 Cortland concept. A few purveyors of culinary goodness that likely couldn't make it/afford to do their own thing, given a space to come together and bring their talents to the masses. Or at least the Bernal Heights crowd. And this adventurous yelper.

Paulie's is a worthy part of the space. Uber friendly and uber good. I wasn't feeling any of the meat options and asked if I could get something with just veggies, and that was no problem at all. Figured the pickles were most important anyway.

The sandwich was deliciously huge, the side lentil salad was an unexpected bonus and I really appreciated the offer to take a dollar off since I didn't want meat. Very cool, and why don't you take it right back as a tip.
author: Jason B.

description: Not a huge fan of the pickles here actually but the lox is amazing!! I've been waiting forever for a place to have lox this good in Sf and even near me! I live in Bernal
author: LadyJ M.

description:
Paulie's is the real deal.  Everything I have had here has been great!
All of the salads contain some of their house-made pickled ingredients (beans, jalapenos, etc), and are flipping delicious.
The pickles are amazing, and the sauerkraut is seriously off the hook.  I accidentally ate the entire jar in one sitting.
Once you go Paulies, you will never go back.
author: Mic H.

description: Whoa! Loved everything I got here. Got the brie sandwich, with an amazing spread, and it came with a small side of salad (I choose potato). Had to get a pickle of course. Yummy! Reminds me of the corner deli we used to have in my neighborhood, friendly customer service and great sandwiches!
author: Theresa D.

description:
The BEST deli sandwiches I ever had...!!
Love the place, but I miss the empanadas place that use to share the space.
Worth going ...!!!
author: Castro E.

description: Came here with my mom to grab a quick bite to eat. I had a tuna sandwich and it was great. Not too dry and perfectly moist. Their onion bread is very good. Wasn't really a big fan of their pickles though. Definitely a good place to grab a bite.
author: Darius A.

description: Best pickles, best Jewish style deli in SF, best brisket and cole slaw- My mouth waters just thinking i might eat there.
author: Darcy L.

description:
Took my husband here for his birthday as he is a serious pickle fiend. He was not disappointed.

We were greeted by Paulie and his wife upon arrival. Paulie then treated my husband to samples of everything he offers. I'm not into pickles, but my husband loved the garlic dills and the zesty originals. He was super happy to take home a jar of the perfectly crunchy garlic dills.

We also had brie sandwiches, which came with our choice of salads. We both chose the grilled slaw. AMAZING, fresh and delicious. 

All around, this place rocks. There's nowhere inside to eat, but there are plenty of benches on the street and they work just fine. Thanks to Paulie for making my husband's birthday special!
author: Jayne G.

description:
I love this place. Granted, I am a little bit obsessed with pickles (garlic dill pickled cucumbers especially), but this place is a delight. The folks that runs it are charming and personable, and hold up well during the lunch rush. They give samples, which to me is essential if I'm going to shell out more than supermarket prices for pickles. 

Today I took a friend and a coworker to Paulie's for lunch. Coworker was stressed out and semi-snarly; friend was his usual even-keeled self, but hungry. The tuna sandwich and cucumber salad converted my coworker into a completely different, much happier person. We all loved our sandwiches, and I finally bought a jar of the OH DEAR CHTHULHU THEY ARE SO TASTY AND CRUNCHY garlic dills. Sorry about the shouting there. When we were eating our food in nearby Holly Park, my friends were being that vocal about how good everything was. The coleslaw looks like my mayo-free Asian slaw, but was different - subtle and complex flavors. Yum. Small coworker and small me also appreciated that we could make two meals out of one Paulie's sandwich.

Back at work, I offered my cuke salad to my vegetarian coworkers to try. They inhaled it. Then I opened the jar of pickles. Pickle nirvana. It had been a rough day and Paulie's quite seriously upped morale.

I am looking forward to trying their horseradish and sauerkraut (unpasteurized, hooray), and maybe even the pickled Brussels sprouts. You've gotta be sure of your recipes if you're selling pickled Brussels sprouts.   

Especially recommended if you're from the Eastern Seaboard or PA. Can't exactly explain why, but you'll get it if you try their wares.

Now...how do I get them to hook up with a Korean restaurant so the restaurant's panchan includes their pickled things?
author: Ess D.

description: I had a tuna melt, grilled slaw, a garlic dill pickle and a mexican chocolate egg cream (don't judge me).  The food was good. I dock them one point for service--the lady working wasn't overly friendly. Actually, she wasn't friendly at all.  However, since I don't live far, I'll go back to try other sandwiches.
author: Emille L.

description:
I get a little thrill when I discover something I wish I'd tried sooner.

My first purchase here was brisket on rye.  It was fabulous and gigantic.  I wanted to eat it all in one sitting but just couldn't manage.  I enjoyed one sandwich for two days!  

I'm looking forward to another brisket sandwich and to trying other kinds.
author: Carol K.

description: We picked up a jar of Paulie's Zesty Original pickles at the Bluxome St. Winery "Meet Market" on Saturday. They are THE best pickles I can remember purchasing. So crisp and savory. I'm intrigued to learn they sell sandwiches and other pickled objects at their Bernal spot - definitely need to check it out.
author: Lindsay M.

description: The pickles are very good, just cured to the right level so they aren't soggy.  I dig the sandwiches too.  Brisket is excellent, despite being heated in a small toaster oven.  The pickled Jalapeno melt is great but beware the mayo.  It's not just a little.  You might want to ask them to go light on mayo if you didn't grow up drinking Helman's from the teet.
author: Paul T.

description: BEST pickles ever. and the jalapeno cheddar melt is something i live for. Thank god we work in the nieghborhood :)
author: michelle h.

description: I'm very skeptical when it comes to Jewish food because nobody does it like grandma, right? Paulie's does a good job of the brisket and chicken liver sandwich, minus the dressing. Pickles are awesome, especially the complimentary chopped pickles with dill. Jars of pickles are available to take home.
author: Marina N.

description: This place is amazing, I have family in the area and I visit once every two weeks and always go here.  Their sandwiches are all amazing and very filling.  The meat is always great and the fish always perfect.   They need a little more space and a few more staff, but their product is amazing and I seriously cannot get enough.  The pickles great, the cucumber salad, I honestly can say I like everything (I have tried) on their menu (I haven't tried the liver yet tbh).    the brisket, corned beef, salmon -- I'm done writing this review because It's making me want to run up there.  The price is very reasonable and great portions.
author: Jonol S.

description:
Great Sandwiches...Quick and tasty !
Gotta try the cauliflower-hands down the best around...
author: Matt G.

description: By far my favorite sandwich place in the city. It's delish. Only downside is that there isn't any seating. But it makes for a great "to go" sandwich that you can take up to Bernal Hill for a nice view.
author: Sarah O.

description: Went in today and they didn't have the Reuben or the chopped liver. The Brisket was basic, not flavorful. Watched the worker handle money and take orders then not wash her hands and touch others peoples food. I had to ask her to wash her hands before she handled my order.
author: Ellen G.

description: Killer sammich. I found the lox sandwich to be awesome, however, the tuna melt was a little dill heavy, and tended to be ever so slightly overpowering. The pickles are amazing, and I've heard excellent things about the brisket. The latkes were also pretty tasty. Definitely on the expensive side, but well worth it.
author: Joseph O.

description: Made a yelp account just to leave a good review for this place. The braised brisket sandwich is absolutely delicious and I went through a jar of the garlic and dill pickles in two days. That's some bomb ass food!
author: Danny S.

description: I'm not a sandwich kind of gal...but I CRAVE their braised brisket and brisket reuben. And their pickles...oh my gosh, so amazing. they don't have much of a place to sit and eat but we usually go to the bar up the street to enjoy a beer with our meal :)
author: Lizzy R.

description: Friendly and cute workers! The tuna sandwich is the bomb! The kugel is yummy in my tummy! I hope this business finds it's forever home and that they thrive here in San Francisco!
author: Mami C.

description: Yum!  I love this place!  Lucky for me, I work just upstairs from Paulie's Pickling and find myself here often.  My recent favorite sandwiches include the Tuna Melt and Pickled Jalapeño  & Cheddar.  I'm also a huge fan of the pickled string beans & the pickled cauliflower....oh, and their sauerkraut is perfectly crunchy & well balanced.  If you're in the 'hood, definitely check Paulie's out - highly recommended!!
author: Elizabeth W.

description: Picked up a jar of their garlic dill pickles. They are fantastic! Crispy, fresh and just the right amount of favors.  Highly recommend!
author: Loren S.

description:
"not from a can" Tuna is the best tuna you will get at a deli. Add Paulie's spread for a yummy kick.

The brisket sandwich is aslo delicious with slaw and russian dressing,

I have ordered at different times the lox, the chicken liver, the Jalapeno pickles, the pickled green beans, All type dill pickles, and pickled turnip to use in place of horseradish for rueben sandwiches. Perfection!
author: Mabel S.

description: After the hillside garage sale, I was hungry and I knew exactly where I wanted to go for some food time. I knew I wanted a sandwich and I got what I wanted. I love pickles and anything pickled. I chose the pickled jalapeno and cheddar cheese sandwich. It was big and delicious. Forget about meat, this was hearty and it hit the spot. How can you not love pickled jalapenos. It wasn't spicy at all--more zesty and crazy good. Will be back to try more of their delicious delicacies.
author: Mel P.

description: Paulie's Pickling now has whitefish salad, their own cream cheese, and smoked salmon (lox) on a regular basis... plus they distribute bagels from House of Bagels! Oooh and they make amazing egg creams.  It's fantastic to see how they've boosted their selection.
author: Michael S.

description: We've been going here since it opened. They have a great selection of pickled items (not just "pickles"), all made from local veggies and other ingredients. Not cheap, but we've been trying to pickle things at home and Paulie's definitely gives us a huge appreciation of how difficult good pickling can be. Everything we've had here has been perfect: beans, cukes, cauliflowers, onions and recently herring (AMAZING!!!). They also now have deli items, like sandwiches, lox, side salads. All really good. Had their whitefish spread with bagels this weekend. Sooooo good. Prices are not cheap, but you get what you pay for. This is all top quality stuff through and through.
author: Arkay K.

description:
These guys' pickles are fantastic!  A friend was nice enough to bring me a jar of their zesty originals and garlic+dill.  Both are tasty, but my personal tastes skew to the zesty's.  Both had lots of crunch and complex, even flavor.  

Haven't had a chance to go by the storefront and try one of their sandwiches yet, but am really looking forward to it.  By the looks of their menu, they make everything themselves.  That in and of itself is impressive.  Personally, if I see the ubiquitous Boar's Head sticker on your door, I turn right around and walk out.  That simple sign shows you don't know or care about what makes a great sandwich.  Will update once I get one of their sammies in my face!
author: Erick M.

description: Love the house lox and tuna melt! Pickles are delish too.
author: Al K.

description: Just happened on this place (and the rest of the very interesting food coop here) while running errand down the street. We dropped in to grab a sandwich. What a surprise! Amazingly fresh tuna sandwich, the best whitefish salad I've had outside of NYC, and last but not least... crisp, super delicious and unusual pickles. I brought a jar of the pickled green tomatoes and green beans home. Worth a visit to Bernal Heights for these treats!
author: Amelia B.

description: Passing through Bernal, wanted to stop for a quick bite. There is no seating here, and a significant wait, but the sandwiches are high quality. My egg salad sandwich was delicious and DH's beef brisket was to die for. Taking off 1 star because they forgot to toast my bread.
author: SF Soccer Mom S.

description: I love this place! Delicious sides to go. Just grab a Piroshki at the other kiosk and you're set!
author: E B.

description:
Everything I have tried from Paulie's has been outstanding.  Best pickles ever, according to my 4 year old son.  I agree.  Plus their chopped liver is to die for - my fave sandwich is the chopped liver and brisket with slaw.  Yummy yum yum!  

Super nice people, delicious food, refreshing lemonade - what''s not to love?
author: Debbie E.

description: Incredible food and home made sodas.  Only drawback is there is no seating, but the food is worth it.
author: Jeff R.

description: All the salads here are amazing.  Great mix of beans, grains, and some heat sometimes.
author: Melinda C.

description:
I happened upon this little marketplace two days ago, and I can't get it out of my mind!  At Paulie's I tried a "Not from a Can" tuna sandwich, lentil salad, potato salad, barley salad, and a cherry mint drink.  The sandwich was a spin on classic tuna salad - with relish, celery, lemon and mayo and topped with lettuce and pickled onions on a roll (I had poppyseed, it was delish).  It didn't look that big, but I could only eat half (and I was hungry).  I *loved* the lentil salad (made with pickled carrots, maybe cinnamon?) and potato salad (made with lots of dill and pickled green bean pieces, no mayo).  The barley salad was a little strong for my taste, with feta and sundried tomato strips, but I think that was just a personal preference (and btw, I ate it all anyway).  I think a whole sandwich which comes with a side salad was $7, so pretty reasonable considering the quality.

Paulie's shares its space with 5 (?) other vendors, so it's almost like going to a permanent farmers market - other vendors have sushi, organic produce, cutlery, vegan baked goods (this is Bernal after all), and yummy-looking empanadas.  I am dying to go back!
author: Lynn S.

description: Samies are better than average, but the pickles are divine and some are still pickled in grandma's crock. Great Bernal biz with a legacy of pickle perfection.
author: Steve S.

description: I can only speak for their super crisp, delicious pickles and their chimichurri sauce: DELICIOUS!!!! Hope to get back there sometime soon to try their sandwiches...
author: Diane C.

description: Fantastic sandwiches. Pulled pork is awesome. The beef is even better. The only thing that is not perfect is that the sandwiches are a bit cold. I'm ok with sandwiches not being hot - but these tend to be a few degrees below perfection. Still 5 stars though.
author: Fred A.

description:
First off, this marketplace is so cool.  Just really great food and great to be able to support local businesses.

Second - The pickles here are STELLAR.  Bought some zesty originals and garlic dill - both are amazing.  They are perfectly flavored and fresh and crunchy at the same time.  Paulie was pickling right there next to us.  They were so nice and let us have a little taste of everything.  First class pickling.  I will be back!
author: Abby G.

description: God I love the sandwiches from this place.  They're huge, so sometimes I just go for the half-sandwich and it's plenty.  With every sandwich you get to choose a side salad (quinoa, lentils, potato salad, slaw, pasta) and they're all really good.
author: Chris F.

description: Hands down the best pickles. I've had the dill pickles and green beans. I'm looking forward to try the pickled cauliflowers. I also had the tuna melt with Paulie's special sauce which was a nice touch of spicy. Great food and great pickles. Def worth to trip!
author: Emily W.

description: I have been to this place twice and both times have been awesome. The place is run by a super friendly couple in a co op . I tried my friends tuna melt and it was amazing. It had some secret sauce that really made the sandwich. I had the braised brisket on rye. It was a giant pile of delicious meat with slaw and dressing and it came with a great pasta salad. I also had the corned beef and that was good too. can't wait to try the pickles
author: mark h.

description: My Mother made pickles at home, and this is the closest to hers that I have ever tasted. Their sandwiches are fantastic. The only reason this is not a 5 star rating is the space these guys occupy in a "Co-Op" arrangement is just too small. A dining area with a few tables would be terrific. Otherwise this place is great for that quick lunch. Take a jar of pickles home to put in the fridge. Or two. Or three.
author: MAURICE C.

description: Recently purchased a jar of the Zesty pickles.  As long as Paulie keeps pickling in SF...the Vlasik Stork is permanently grounded !
author: Tom B.

description: The best chopped liver!!!!  And on Cortland Ave, not Brooklyn or Manhattan.  What a really big treat.  The shared marketplace delivers some Ferry Buliding benefits to our local hood.  Great concept for Bernal.  Yummy spot--check it out.
author: H B.

description: so cute.  in the new tiny bernal marketplace right across from the vegan bakery (literally, like, two feet).  has a bunch of salads...lentil salad, shells with tomato and amazing potato salad.  and some kick ass lemonade--blackberry mint on saturday and hibsicus on sunday.  they have sandwiches as well.  can't wait to buy a jar of pickles.
author: kate s.

description: This place should have a line around the block. Outstanding homemade deli sandwiches. Sublme brisket. The best chicken salad ever. Great chopped liver. You can tell they use top quality meats. Try it!
author: Matthew K.

description: Finally mde into the Bernal Marketplace. What an amazing concept.  I had been wanting to tryZOVIRAX® (acyclovir) Cream 5% ickles since they opened but never could get my act together. Until today. The classic Garlic & Dill is a very good pickle. It takes me back to the pickle barrels of my youth in a deli on Kedzie Avenu on Chicagos North side. But it pales in comparison to the HALF SOUR, a non vinegar naturally brine fermented pickle. This the REAL DEAL. And Paulies half sour is way more sour than most pickles FULL sour. Yet it is still crisp, full of fresh pickle flavor. You want to jut suck the brine off it. Then...wait for it.....there is......CHOPPED LIVER!  I am going to have that for lunch tomorrow. A chopped liver sandwich.  I only had a taste, but this was a chopped liver that should be world famous. From New York to Chicago, to LA and beyond, I dare you to find better chopped liver. Eat this food!
author: Gary G.
